docs.abstract: Excessive alcohol consumption, including binge drinking, is responsible for 10 percent of deaths among working age adults in the United States, according to a new report.

docs.lead_paragraph: HUTTER--Dr. Robert V.P., a renowned pathologist died July 2, surrounded by his wife and children in New Jersey, at 85, after years with Alzheimer's disease. A past president of the American Cancer Society, former chairman of the department of pathology at St. Barnabas Medical Center, former editor-in-chief of the journal Cancer, he shaped cancer prevention strategies nationally and internationally. At the ACS, he helped to launch the society's first nutrition guidelines. He was the rare pathologist sought out by cancer patients for advice and what they got in return was a compassionate expert with sensitivity and honesty. Born May 25th, 1929 in Yonkers, NY, he attended Syracuse University on scholarship, played football for Coach F. Ben Schwartzwalder, graduated from SUNY Health Science Center at Syracuse, did his residency at Yale University and at Memorial Sloan-Kettering, served two years of active duty in the Navy, returned to Memorial, then to Yale and became a tenured professor of pathology at the age of 39. In 1970, he served for three years as chairman of pathology at the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey and subsequently moved to St. Barnabas. He is survived by his wife, the former Ruth Lauterbach, son Andrew (Barbara), daughters Randi (Stuart) and Edie, and ten grandchildren.
